abstract.t: This document presents an extension that allows activities on social objects to be expressed within the Atom Syndication Format.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Atom Syndication Format, as defined in , is widely used to transmit various types of web content such as weblog posts, news headlines, as well as user activities within social sites. In the case of user activities, Atom lacks the ability to express much of the activity-specific metadata in a machine-parseable format. Activity Streams is an XML format designed to allow this additional activity metadata to be expressed within existing Atom entries and feeds.

It is a goal of this specification to provide sufficient metadata about an activity such that a consumer of the data can present it to a user in a rich human-friendly format. This may include constructing readable sentences about the activity that occurred, visual representations of the activity, or combining similar activities for display.

section.title: Notational Conventions
section.t: The XML Namespaces URI [W3C.REC-xml-names-19990114] for the XML elements and attributes described in this specification is: http://activitystrea.ms/spec/1.0/.

In this document, this namespace is referred to as "the AtomActivity namespace", and the namespace prefix "activity:" is used for the above namespace URI. The namespace prefix "atom:" is used for the namespace URI http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom. The namespace prefix "thr:" is used for the namespace URI http://purl.org/syndication/thread/1.0. The choices of namespace prefix are arbitrary and not semantically significant.

This specification uses a shorthand form of terms from the XML Infoset [W3C.REC-xml-infoset-20040204]. The phrase "Information Item" is omitted when naming element and attribute information items. Therefore, when this specification uses the term "element," it is referring to an element information item in infoset terms. Likewise, when this specification uses the term "attribute," it is referring to an attribute information item.

This specification allows the use of IRIs . Every URI is also an IRI, so a URI may be used wherever an IRI is named. When an IRI that is not also a URI is given for dereferencing, it MUST be mapped to a URI using the steps in Section 3.1 of . When an IRI is serving as an identifier, it MUST NOT be so mapped.
The text of this specification provides the sole definition of conformance. Examples in this specification are non-normative.
This specification uses "the Atom specification" to refer to .

section.title: Activity Concepts
section.t: In its simplest form, an activity consists of an actor, a verb, and an object. It tells the story of a person performing an action on or with an object -- "Geraldine posted an photo" or "John shared a video". In most cases these elements will be explicitly declared, but they may also be implied.

section.title: The Activity Construct
section.t: An activity consists of the following logical components:

section.title: ID
section.t: This absolute URI value conveys a permanent, universally unique identifier for the activity. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one ID value.
(TODO: Still some question as to whether this should be part of the Activity construct, rather than just part of the Atom representation)

section.title: Time
section.t: A [Date Construct] that identifies the time at which the activity occurred. It is important to note that this is not necessarily the same as the time at which the activity was published. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one Time value.

section.title: Actor
section.t: An Object Construct that identifies the entity that performed the activity. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one actor.

section.title: Verb
section.t: An absolute URI value that identifies the action of the activity. An Activity construct MUST have at least one verb, and MAY have more than one.

If an activity contains more than one verb, all verbs MUST be generalizations or specializations of one another. For example, the general verb "to experience" might be specialized by a verb "to listen to". If a more specific verb is used, publishers SHOULD also include all of its more general verbs so that a consumer may use the most specific verb it understands.

An activity consumer SHOULD use the most specific verb it understands within each entry. If none of the activity's verbs are understood by the consumer, it MAY use other information to infer the verb, or the consumer MAY use the content of the activity title, summary and/or content to obtain a human-readable description of the activity.

section.title: Object
section.t: This Object Construct identifies the primary object of the activity. An Activity construct MUST have exactly one object.

section.title: Target
section.t: The target of an activity is an Object Construct that represents the object to which the activity was performed. The exact meaning of an activity's target is dependent on the verb of the activity, but will often be the object of the English preposition "to". For example, in the activity "John saved a movie to his wishlist", the target of the activity is 'wishlist'. The activity target MUST NOT be used to identify an indirect object that is not a target of the activity. An Activity construct MAY have a target, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: Generator
section.t: The generator of an activity identifies that application which created it, which may be separate from the service to which the activity is published. For example, a third-party application on a mobile phone may be used to post a photo to a photo sharing service. The activity generator is identified by a name and optional URI. An Activity construct MAY have a generator, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: The Object Construct
section.t: An object construct is a thing, real or imaginary, which participates in an activity. It may be the entity performing the activity, or the entity on which the activity was performed. An object consists of the following logical components:

section.title: ID
section.t: The id of an object construct is an absolute URI that uniquely identifies the object. An Object construct MUST have exactly one ID value.

section.title: Name
section.t: This string value provides a human readable display name for the object, if the object has a name. An Object construct MAY have a name, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: URL
section.t: This URI value identifies an HTML representation of the object. An Object construct MAY have a URL, but MUST NOT have more than one.

section.title: Object Type
section.t: This absolute URI identifies the type of object. An Object construct MAY have one or more types.

If an object contains more than one object type, all types MUST be generalizations or specializations of one another. For example, the general type "article" might be specialized by the type "weblog entry". If a more specific type is used, publishers SHOULD also include all of its more general types so that a consumer may use the most specific type it understands.

Activity consumers SHOULD use the most specific object type that they understand within each entry. The consumer MAY use other information to infer the object type if it does not recognize any of the object types given. If it cannot infer the object type, a consumer MUST act as though no object type is present.

If no object type is present, the object has no specific type. Consumers SHOULD refer to such objects only by their titles. For example, when forming an activity sentence a consumer might say "Johan posted 'My Cat'" rather than "Johan posted a photo: 'My Cat'".

section.title: Atom Representation
section.t: Activities are represented in an Atom document using a combination of conventions and custom extension elements. Activities are represented using atom:entry elements but may exist in one of two forms, an Activity Entry or an Object Entry.

section.title: Activity represented as atom:entry
section.t: Any valid Atom entry as defined by section 4.1.2 of is a representation of one or more activities as defined in .

If the atom:entry contains at least one activity:verb element and at least one activity:object element then it is a full activity entry and MUST be processed as described in . Otherwise the entry is an implied activity shorthand entry and MUST be processed as described in .

Although there is not a one-to-one mapping between an Atom entry and an activity, consumers SHOULD retain the value of the atom:id element from which each activity was produced such that these activities can be identified should an entry be referred to by another Atom feature which is not aware of the extensions defined in this specification. This id is not unique across all activities and has no semantic singificance for Activity Streams processing.

section.title: Full Activity Entry
section.t: A full activity entry represents a selection of one or more activities which refer to different objects but all share the same values for the other activity properties.

The atom:author element which applies to the entry, as defined by section 4.2.1 of , represents the actor of the represented activities. This element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .

If the entry element has as a direct child an activity:target element then this element represents the target of the represented activities. This element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .
The atom:published chlid element of the entry, as defined in section 4.2.9 of , represents the time of the represented activities.
Each activity:verb child element of the entry represents a verb for the represented activities.

If the entry has as a direct child an atom:generator element then it MUST be processed as defined in section 4.2.4 of and its name and URI used for the generator property of the represented activities.

Each activity:object child element of the entry represents the object of an activity whose other properties are represented as described above. Each element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .
The set of activities represented by a full activity entry is the set of activities created by combining the object represented by each activity:object element with the other common properties.

section.title: Implied Activity Shorthand
section.t: An implied activity shorthand entry represents exactly one activity in terms of its object.
The atom:published chlid element of the entry, as defined in section 4.2.9 of , represents the time of the represented activity.

If the entry has as direct children one or more activity:verb elements, each of these elements represents a verb for the represented activity. If the entry has no activity:verb child elements, the represented activity is implied to have only the "post" verb as defined in [TODO: write this section and xref].
If the entry has as a direct child an atom:generator element then it MUST be processed as defined in section 4.2.4 of and its name and URI used for the generator property of the represented activity.

If the set of verbs for the represented activity includes the "post" verb, the atom:author element which applies to the entry, as defined by section 4.2.1 of , represents the actor of the represented activity. If the set of verbs does not include the "post" verb then the containing atom:feed element MUST have an atom:author element as its direct child and this element represents the actor of the represented activity. This appropriate atom:author element MUST be processed into an object construct as defined in .

The atom:entry element itself MUST also be processed into an object construct as defined in and used as the object of the represented activity. If the set of verbs for the represented activity does not include the "post" verb then the atom:published child element MUST be ignored when doing this processing, because the date therein represents the date of the activity and not the publication date of the object.
The represented activity of an implied activity shorthand entry does not have a target.

section.title: Object Representations
section.t: Objects can be represented in a variety of forms depending on context. All of these representations encode the data model described for the object construct in . These representations are used in various contexts within the Atom representation of an activity as described in .

section.title: Object represented as atom:entry
section.t: In this section, "the entry" refers to the atom:entry element which is representing the object.
The title of the entry, determined as defined in section 4.2.14 of , represents the title of the represented object.
The publication time of the entry as defined in section 4.2.9 of , unless elided from processing as defined in , represents the publication time of the represented object.
The id of the entry, as defined in section 4.2.6 of , represents the id of the represented object.
The href attribute of the first atom:link element in document order that is a child of the entry and whose link relation type is "alternate" represents the URL of the represented object.
Each activity:object-type element which is a direct child of the entry represents an object type for the represented object.
Other descendent elements of the entry may represent other extension properties defined by the object types of the represented object.

section.title: Object represented as atom:author
section.t: In this section, "the author element" refers to the atom:author element which is representing the object.
The name of the author element, determined as defined in section 3.2.1 of , represents the title of the represented object.

The first atom:id child element of the author element, processed as defined in section 4.2.6 of , represents the id of hte represented object. The use of atom:id as a child of atom:author is an extension defined by this specification.

If the author element contains any atom:link child elements whose link relation types are "alternate", the href attribute of the first such element represents the URL of the represented object. Otherwise, the value of the first atom:uri child element, as defined in section 3.2.2 of , represents the URL of the represented object.
Each activity:object-type element which is a direct child of the author element represents an object type for the represented object.
Other descendent elements of the entry may represent other extension properties defined by the object types of the represented object.

section.title: Object represented as activity:object or activity:target
section.t: In this section, "the object element" refers to the activity:object or activity:target element which is representing the object.
The title of the object element, determined in the same way as defined for the atom:entry element in section 4.2.14 of , represents the title of the represented object.
The publication time of the object element, determined in the same way as as defined for the atom:entry element in section 4.2.9 of , represents the publication time of the represented object.
The id of the entry, determined in the same way as defined for the atom:entry element in section 4.2.6 of , represents the id of the represented object.
The href attribute of the first atom:link element in document order that is a child of the object entry and whose link relation type is "alternate" represents the URL of the represented object.
Each activity:object-type element which is a direct child of the object element represents an object type for the represented object.
Other descendent elements of the entry may represent other extension properties defined by the object types of the represented object.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: As this specification defines an extension to the Atom Syndication Format, it is subject to the same security considerations defined in .

Publishers or Consumers implementing Activity Streams as a stream of public data may also want to consider the potential for unsolicited commercial or malicious content and should take preventative measures to recognize such content and either identify it or not include it in their stream implementations.
Publishers should take reasonable measures to make sure potentially malicious user input such as cross-site scripting attacks are not included in the Activity Streams data they publish.
Consumers that re-emit ingested content to end-users MUST take reasonable measures if emitting ingested content to make sure potentially malicious ingested input is not re-emitted.

Consumers that re-emit ingested content for crawling by search engines should take reasonable measures to limit any use of their site as a Search Engine Optimization loophole. This may include converting un-trusted hyperlinks to text or including a rel="nofollow" attribute.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: None.

section.title: Examples
section.t: This appendix is non-normative. Where these examples include fragments of XML documents, assume the namespace declarations xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:activity="http://activitystrea.ms/spec/1.0/" are in scope.

figure.postamble: This example shows a typical activity entry using the post verb defined by this specification and a hypothetical "photo" object type. It also demonstrates the use of atom:title and atom:content to provide fallback content for feed processors that do not support activity extensions. An activity stream application might render this entry into the sentence "Geraldine posted a photo titled 'My Cat' in Geraldine's Photos", with the photo title and the source feed title presented as links.
